content.body:
where is the module instance cache stored? ExecutionContext? Realm?

```js
const mod = module { console.log('run') }
const mod2 = static module { import 'mod' }

await import(new Module(mod2, async () => mod), {})
await import(new ExecutionContext.Module(mod2, async () => mod, {}))
```

content.body: how many time `mod` is executed?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: how many time `mod` is executed?
how many time mod is executed?

content.body: I would expect it to only be executed once in the original execution context (the one where the module block expression was evaluated).
The cache could be a [[ModuleRecord]] internal slot on the Module object
ok thanks!

> <@kriskowal:matrix.org> I think low-level import reflection or deferred import do obviate one complication of the Compartment design (as written right now), regarding how to communicate a module source or module instance from a host compartment to a child compartment. That isn’t possible to express in terms of the low-level parts, which compels the developer to use import reflection or deferred import explicitly. That might be a good outcome, even for XS. Currently XS depends on a manifest to express the full working set, but these features together would allow tooling to take over more of the tedium.

Yes, it feels like import reflection and deferred import evaluation are both doing the same thing in that they hide some of the complexity that a full-access low level api would give. Module loading is quite complex, so choosing what should be hidden and how is probably a good idea. I do worry though that we will add a lot of things to the static import statement / dynamic import options bag, and that will confuse people (as i've already had feedback on that). But this is a concern for later.

That isn’t possible to express in terms of the low-level parts, which compels the developer to use import reflection or deferred import explicitly. That might be a good outcome, even for XS. Currently XS depends on a manifest to express the full working set, but these features together would allow tooling to take over more of the tedium.
Yes, it feels like import reflection and deferred import evaluation are both doing the same thing in that they hide some of the complexity that a full-access low level api would give. Module loading is quite complex, so choosing what should be hidden and how is probably a good idea. I do worry though that we will add a lot of things to the static import statement / dynamic import options bag, and that will confuse people (as i've already had feedback on that). But this is a concern for later.

content.body: I found we need a `isAsync` property on the Virtual Module.
content.formatted_body: I found we need a isAsync property on the Virtual Module.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: I found we need a `isAsync` property on the Virtual Module.
I found we need a isAsync property on the Virtual Module.

content.body: `Cyclic Module Records` requires [[isAsync]] which is not possible for Virtual Module because it does not have a source text to be parsed.
content.formatted_body: Cyclic Module Records requires [[isAsync]] which is not possible for Virtual Module because it does not have a source text to be parsed.

content.body: I had wondered about that and XS managed to make it work without it. Very good to know.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I had wondered about that and XS managed to make it work without it. Very good to know.

content.body: It might be a spec bug. 🤷‍♂️

content.body:
> <@kriskowal:matrix.org> I had wondered about that and XS managed to make it work without it. Very good to know.

XS have JS source at build time, they can know if the module has TLA or not.
We need to manually mark it for virtual modules (like `needsImportMeta`), otherwise I guess we need to rewrite the spec a lot.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @kriskowal:matrix.org
I had wondered about that and XS managed to make it work without it. Very good to know.
XS have JS source at build time, they can know if the module has TLA or not.
We need to manually mark it for virtual modules (like needsImportMeta), otherwise I guess we need to rewrite the spec a lot.

We need to manually mark it for virtual modules (like needsImportMeta), otherwise I guess we need to rewrite the spec a lot.

content.body: XS also implemented a draft of the virtual module source protocol.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: XS also implemented a draft of the virtual module source protocol.

content.body: And they are of the opinion that the virtual module source doesn’t have to reveal whether initialize() returns a promise or not.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: And they are of the opinion that the virtual module source doesn’t have to reveal whether initialize() returns a promise or not.

content.body: Though, if it is necessary, it is not a problem to require it to be reflected on the virtual module source object.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Though, if it is necessary, it is not a problem to require it to be reflected on the virtual module source object.

content.body: Just might be worth inquiring with vendors whether the spec can be relaxed. Module records capture a lot of details from multiple conflated layers that get initialized at different stages.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Just might be worth inquiring with vendors whether the spec can be relaxed. Module records capture a lot of details from multiple conflated layers that get initialized at different stages.

content.formatted_body:
Clarification:

const mod1 = module { console.log('run') };
const src2 = static module { import 'mod' };
const ctx2 = new ExecutionContext(globalThis);
const mod2 = new ctx2.Module(src2, async () => mod1);
await import(mod1);
await import(mod2);

I expect this to log run once from the host execution context.

content.body: Linking modules between independent execution contexts is an explicit goal out to full Compartment parity, for supply chain isolation.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Linking modules between independent execution contexts is an explicit goal out to full Compartment parity, for supply chain isolation.

content.body: And notably, shared intrinsics between separate execution contexts.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: And notably, shared intrinsics between separate execution contexts.
